text:
Thought experiment.
What's the worst that could happen if we allowed anyone to use Registror to trigger a release of a package?
Rather than just people with permissions. :thread:

text:
If the version hasn't been incremented since last release but changes have been pushed.

So triggering a release will just be rejected as that release already has been made

text:
If the version number has been incremented to and given a `-DEV` prerelease suffix. Like Julia does, and like ColPrac recommends.
And changes have been pushed.

Then release will be rejected since can't register releases with a SemVer prerelease suffix

text:
I thought maybe there could be a problem where some bad actor creates a branch that doesn't get merged to master, and they register that branch.
But that would be rejected since that branch would not be on the registered repo, it would be on the bad actor's fork.
Unless the bad actor had rights to create branches on the main repo.
But at that point they would also have rights to use Registror today

text:
One case is if you incremented the version number.
But did not tag a release yet and did not add a prerelease suffix.
A bad actor here could register something while you were still in the middle of making a series of changes that you wanted to register all at once.

That would be kinda shit.
Especially since it would trigger CompatHelper
